title: Keelmans Way Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: Newbiggin Hall Scouts / Keelmans way
images.caption: View of the path just east of Wylam

images.title: Newbiggin Hall Scouts / Messing about on the river Tyne
images.caption: Messing about on the river Tyne

images.title: John Clive Nicholson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Tyne from Newburn Bridge

images.title: David Rogers / Stella Staith
images.caption: Stella Staith, Blaydon. Little evidence remains of the Towneley Main Waggonway which brought coal from Stargate Pit to the River Tyne at Stella Staith (without an e). The plaque on this support for the waggonway does not refer to the mining heritage of the area but to Blaydon Races which were run on nearby Blaydon Island and Stella Haugh.

images.title: Chris Bell, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Blaydon

images.title: Tom Brewis / View from The Slide toward Liberty Monument with Goodshieldhaugh in foreground
images.caption: View from The Slide toward Liberty Monument with Goodshieldhaugh in foreground. A reclaimed slag heap which has greatly enhanced local amenity. Part of the Derwent Country Park which is run expertly by Gateshead Council - an example for any local authority.

images.title: Mick Garratt / Viaduct Over the River Derwent
images.caption: Viaduct Over the River Derwent. Supposedly nine arches although only five in view here. Now carrying the Derwent Walk footpath and cycleway.

images.title: Brian Abbott / Weir on the River Derwent
images.caption: Weir on the River Derwent

description: This 10 mile walking and cycling trail runs along the River Tyne from Wylam to the upper reaches of the Tyne and the Derwent Walk Country Park in Gateshead. The route starts on Wylam Bridge and follows the southern side of the river east. You'll pass Clara Vale, Ryton, Blaydon where you turn south to follow the River Derwent to the visitor centre at Derwent Walk Country Park. The park includes a mixture of woodland, meadows and wetlands with views of the impressive Nine Arches viaduct over the river as well. Here you can also visit the visitor centre and enjoy some well earned refreshments after your exercise.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: The Newburn to Wylam Walk uses part of the trail to create a circular walk between the two riverside settlements. You could use it to visit the north side of the river where you can visit the birthplace of railway pioneer George Stephenson at the National Trust's Stephenson's cottage. For more walking ideas in the area see the Tyne and Wear Walks page.

display_address: Station Road, Wylam Wood, Wylam, Northumberland, North East, England, NE41 8JA, United Kingdom
